utterances: But in court filings and at Gulf Coast meetings, Feinberg defends his program and the $3.5 billion he's paid out as nothing short of extraordinary.
We are doing something right.
That's what he told members of the Florida legislature last week.
Representative Doug Broxson of Gulf Breeze disagrees.
You have created the perfect system to frustrate our constituents and not pay.
Feinberg says he's getting complaints from both sides.
BP says he's being too generous, while local officials say he's being tight-fisted.
I agree that there's a great deal of frustration, and I come back down here and listen to these concerns.
The idea that the Gulf Coast claims facility is not serving the people of Florida is simply untrue.
There are problems that need to be fixed.
It's already too late for many businesses.
Real estate broker Allison Davenport is the vice chair of the Chamber of Commerce in Perdido Key, Florida.
She's spearheading an effort to get the White House's attention.
If somebody taps you for the job, they could un-tap you for the job.
Davenport says it's time for President Obama to step in and make a change.
Debbie Elliott, NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Audie Cornish.
People who volunteer to participate in medical research usually expect to remain anonymous.
That includes those who donate DNA for use in genetic studies.
But now, researchers have shown that, in some cases, they can trace a research subject's DNA back to them.
NPR's Veronique LaCapra reports that with more and more personal information available online, the risk of being identified from our genetic information will only increase.
An international team of scientists wondered how easy it would be to identify people whose DNA had been posted anonymously on the Internet.
They decided to focus on 10 men whose genetic blueprints had been made public for research purposes.
By plugging a bit of the men's genetic information into an online service that helps people trace their family histories, they got back a list of possible relatives.
With that list, and information about the age and home state of the men, Yaniv Erlich, of the Whitehead Institute, says his team identified five of them.

We could actually identify all the other people in the family, basically by looking at public websites, looking at public records of these people, at Facebook and other websites, and be able to connect and to identify all the other people.
They were able to identify about 50 people in all.
Erlich says his study raises big questions about whether it's possible to protect the anonymity of genetic information.
Now, I don't say that everyone now can do this type of study, but it suggests that there is a privacy issue that can be exploited.
And he's not the only one worried about genetic privacy.
Jim Evans, who's a medical geneticist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, says right now, the risk of privacy violations is relatively low.
But he says it's only going to get worse.
We can't put the genie back in the bottle.
Privacy has been continually eroded in the digital universe in which we live.
That's just a fact of life.
Evans says there needs to be a balance between making genetic data available to researchers and protecting people's privacy.
For him, that means limiting who can access genetic information.
We need clear policies for how data are handled, with whom they're shared, and importantly, there need to be penalties for violating those policies.
The fear is that people who volunteer to provide their DNA for research may be vulnerable to genetic discrimination.
But even with the risks, some people are OK with putting their genetic data out there for everyone to see.
That's right.
No smoking gun, legally speaking, but there are just bad optics for Planned Parenthood, especially, you know, graphic scenes in labs at these clinics, which we have again this week.
David Daleiden is the antiabortion activist behind these videos.
He gained a lot of access here, and I think it is striking how clearly he did his homework in this, what he has said is a three-year project.
Here he is in this fifth video.
He is poking through a tray of fetal parts from that day's abortions.
Listen here now, as he points to an eye, how he has this lingo down.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
These orbits are good too 'cause - and at this stage, you start to get the retinal pigment epithelium...
Yes.
...Which is in the back, which is a part you've collected out before (laughter).
So all of...
So he is just speaking as an insider there, but this is gruesome stuff to see.
It's gruesome to talk about it.
And I think this is clearly part of the strategy.
Every time, you know, the media talks about these videos, you can think of it as a win for abortion opponents.
And so much of this is a battle for public opinion.
And Jennifer, you said this was a three-year effort by the abortion opponents, and they have promised many more videos to come.
Daleiden initially said he's got enough for 12 videos.
Now, there have been two restraining orders issued against the release of some of his footage.
In one case, a California company, StemExpress, brought action because California law says you can't record a conversation with another person without that person knowing.
Also, Daleiden is barred for now from using footage from two annual meetings of the National Abortion Federation that also were in California.
The groups says he broke a confidentiality agreement with them and that releasing information on their members poses a risk to their safety.
But you know, with dozens of interviews he says he has, we may well see more videos coming.
We might also see more charges against Daleiden because both the U.S.
attorney general and the California state attorney general are investigating how he set up fake identities and a fake company to carry this out.
OK.
NPR's Jennifer Ludden.
Jennifer, thanks.
Thank you.
And let's turn now to the politics and how this controversy is affecting the presidential race.
NPR's Sarah McCammon joins me for that.
And Sarah, Republicans have seized on this issue.
How has it been playing out on the campaign trail?
Well, Republicans have pretty much universally come out and condemned Planned Parenthood.
But this has been an especially tricky issue for Democrats because women and supporters of abortion rights are a key constituency for them.
So Democrats seem to be kind of walking a fine line in acknowledging that many people do find these videos disturbing but also wanting to stand up for women's health.
Both Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders have criticized the tone of some of the videos while also defending Planned Parenthood as a provider of women's healthcare.
So it's been tricky for some Democrats.
Is there any risk for Republicans on this?
Well, actually, Jeb Bush, former governor of Florida, tripped up over this issue yesterday talking to Southern Baptists in Nashville.
He was asked about funding for Planned Parenthood, and he said, yes, he would defund the organization.
But he took it a step further.
Let's listen to that.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

You could take, dollar for dollar - although, I'm not sure we need a half a billion dollars for women's health issues - but if you took dollar for dollar, there are many extraordinarily fine organizations, communities...
So Bush's suggestion that we might be spending too much on women's health lit up social media.
Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders jumped on it, and Bush, almost as quickly, walked it back, saying he had misspoken.
This isn't the first time, either, I should mention, that Jeb Bush has walked back statements he's made on thorny issues.
You might recall that earlier this year, he had to pull back on statements about whether he would have gone into Iraq and eventually said he wouldn't.
Then there were his comments that Americans need to work more hours.
Well, he said that was about people underemployed who need to be fully employed.
So this is at least the third time Bush has said something on the campaign trail that he had to quickly explain.
And how will the question of abortion and funding for Planned Parenthood continue to reverberate both on the campaign trail and on Capitol Hill?
We're going to hear more about it over the next several months.
Senators Ted Cruz and Rand Paul, both candidates for president on the Republican side - they backed a measure that failed this week in the Senate to defund Planned Parenthood.
But it's not over yet.
They're vowing to resurrect the issue this fall.
And you know, here's where it gets tricky.
There's a faction of Republicans who are threatening a government shutdown over this issue.
They want to tie any funding for government, even temporary funding, to keep the federal government going to Planned Parenthood funding.
So it's really an issue that mobilizes both sides, and expect to hear more about it both on Capitol Hill and the campaign trail.
OK.
That's NPR political reporter Sarah McCammon.
Sarah, thanks.
Thank you.
